What you are doing should of course work.  Are you sure you put the
-Djava.library.path in the VM arguments section in the Run configuration, and
not the program arguments section?  An easy way to tell what Eclipse is running
is to launch using Debug, then right click on the application in the Debug view
and select Properties.  The command line is listed there.

However, I believe the "Run As > SWT Application" feature was designed assuming
you have SWT as a project in your workspace.  You can currently import SWT into
your workspace using one of the following methods:

 1. File > Import... > External Plug-Ins and Fragments > Next > Add SWT > Finish
 2. File > Import... > Existing Project into Workspace > Archive File
    Then add the .zip file of SWT from our webpage (requires RC2 + RC2 SWT .zip)
 3. Checking out SWT from CVS at dev.eclipse.org.

Since the cairo library is not used by Eclipse, it will not be extracted into
the configuration area.  Loading SWT into your workspace ensures that all of the
libraries will be there for you.

You need to make sure you have the .so files that correspond to the version of
the .jar files you have.  Each release of SWT changes the version of the .so
files it requires.  Maybe this is what went wrong?

I think you were overriding the java.library.path from the SWT launcher.  Since
things work for you now, I don't think there's any point in keeping this bug
open.  I am closing this as WORKSFORME.

Please re-open if you are still having trouble.
